Attacking the chief minister, Singh claimed that the government had extended no extra benefit to the MGNREGA workers but just gave them some relief by clearing their dues pending for last several months.

“The chief minister himself mentioned that he was clearing the dues of the MGNREGA workers,” he pointed.

However, the former Congress MLA also thanked the chief minister for clearing the dues of poor workers when they were badly in need of money. “I am thankful to Adityanathji that he at least cleared the dues of MNREGA workers but I want to ask him when he will show the same sympathy towards the cane growers or farmers who too have pending dues?” he asked.

Singh claimed that the cane growers in UP were yet to receive their Rs 9,000 crore cane dues despite the government’s claim that all the dues had been cleared.

Singh said that Prime Minister Narendra Modi also announced to give financial relief to 54 lakh farmers under PM Samman Nidhi scheme but the farmers were still to receive the money in their accounts.

Title: To contain spread of corona every measure is taken: DC
Article:
To contain spread of coronavirus every single possible measure is taken by district administration and to protect the residents from Corona infection, on Monday District Collector issued orders to seal all boundaries of Bhopal district and every person entering the district will be quarantined.

According to the order of District Magistrate and Collector Bhopal Tarun Pithode, all possible measures will be taken to prevent the residents of Bhopal from corona infection and all the boundaries of Bhopal district have been sealed.

Every person entering the district from outside will be compulsorily quarantined. Joints teams of police and administration would be monitoring vehicles coming from outside at check posts on the borders of the adjacent districts of Bhopal, Lalaria Check Post Berasia, Sohaya Check Post Berasia Vidisha-Bhopal,

Rampura Balachon Check Post Berasia Sehore, Bhopal, Parwati Check Post Berasia Sehore and intensive checking of these vehicles done. Only Bhopal residents are allowed to enter the district from these check posts.

After the orders now onwards the residents of any other districts will not be given admission in Bhopal by the district administration. Along with this, the Bhopal residents living outside will be placed in quarantine at places like lodges, community building etc by the administration and as soon as they enter the border of Bhopal, they will be tested for their healthy well- being and would be kept under constant surveillance.

For this district administration has made all arrangements for food and other arrangements.

The district administration has already acquired all the wedding halls, marriage gardens, and community buildings. The operator has been instructed for cleaning, toilet and arranging water and drinking water along with all facilities at their premises.

Title: Continuous supplies of essential items and medicines on
Article:
For the prevention of COVID-19 epidemic in the State, continuous supplies of essential items and medicines are being made in all the districts. Instructions have been issued by the Government to set up a team under the leadership of deputy collector level officer in each district to ensure that these materials reach people and health institutions in time. These teams will report to the Collector daily.

Representatives of Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) have been appointed as District Coordinator in each district and the medical college. These teams will extend support for stock management. These teams will work as a single point of contact for coordination with state level by the district and will keep in touch with the state level monitoring team as required.

All Chief Medical and Health Officers, Civil Surgeons and Medical College of state have been instructed to issue indent to CMHO Bhopal as soon as the material is received.

All of them have been asked to update stock of material received on portal online.

Supply arrangements will be ensured to all district on the basis of this stock updation from Bhopal.

Title: Youngsters extending helping hands to needy and poor
Article:
As there is a nationwide lockdown due to the severe outbreak of Coronavirus, a lot of youngsters are extending their helping hands to the needy and poor people of the city.

The volunteers of Sant Nirankari Charitable Foundation (SNCF) took up the initiative and distributed food packets in different areas of the city on Monday.

With the nationwide lockdown, many families are facing the issue of food storage. Various organizations are working to reach out to the poor families. Here on Monday, SNCF volunteers distributed Food packets consider of Wheat, Rice, edible oil, soap, salt to needy in and around Bhopal. Around 300 Food packages reached in various parts of Bhopal District area, to name with Kolar road area, Piplani area, Bairagarh, Gandhi Nagar and Kayampur.

It is to be noted that the Sant Nirankari Charitable Foundation (SNCF) is an organization with socio-charitable activities as its primary objective and selfless service of humanity as its pivotal philosophy. The Foundation has been formed to effectively implement the broad vision of Sant Nirankari Mission.

Title: BJP urges CM for better coordination
Article:
State BJP has urged Chief Minister Hemant Soren to set up better coordination among various parts of the Government machinery. State BJP spokesperson Pratul Shahdeo today said that at present, there is a huge lack of coordination in the Govt due to which the announcements are not being implemented at the ground level.

Pratul said that the government had announced that food would be provided to the needy from police stations through the Food and Supplies Department, but presently the situation is that very few kitchens are running here. “Wherever they are running, the SHO of the concerned police station is running these community kitchens from his pocket. No help has been reached to the police stations from the government level yet,” he said.

“Similarly, the government had announced that all those returning to Jharkhand would undergo a health test. Only then will they be able to go to their home. But, in recent times, millions of people have returned to Jharkhand. Most of them could not even get basic medical treatment,” he added.

Meanwhile, State BJP general Secretary Anant Ojha said that there is a possibility of serious conspiracy in the State amid Corona crisis. He made this statement today while giving a sharp response to the 24 foreigners caught in the mosque in Hindpiri, Ranchi. Ojha said that it is not the first incident but such hidden foreigners who were from countries like China, Kyrgyzstan, were caught from the mosque situated in Radgaon. Information received regarding the foreigners caught today according to them, they are from countries like Africa, Malaysia etc.a

Title: No new case of COVID-19 reported on Monday
Article:
No new case of the COVID-19 was reported in the State by the health department of Uttarakhand on Monday. The State has so far reported seven positive cases of novel Coronavirus with two patients recovering from the disease.

The director general (DG) of state health services, Dr Amita Upreti said the reports of 18 samples of the suspected patients of the disease were received on Monday and all of them were negative. The department sent swab samples of 43 suspected patients for test of COVID-19 on the day. Eleven samples were collected from civil hospital, Roorkee, ten from Mela hospital in Haridwar and seven from district hospital in Rudraprayag.

The DG informed that 5165 people in different parts of the state are in home and institutional quarantine. The department has so far taken swab samples of 459 suspected patients for COVID-19 test out of which reports of 45 samples are awaited.

Title: Implement heat action plan, DMs told
Article:
With the MeT department forecasting heatwave conditions in Odisha in the next few days, the State Disaster Management Authority has warned that the situation may compound the challenges in containing the spread of coronavirus.

The maximum temperatures have gone up sharply in the past two days; and the MeT department has forecast heat wave conditions from Tuesday.

Odisha State Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA) Managing Director PK Jena has written to the district Collectors to put standard operating procedures (SOPs) in place for implementing the heat action plan.

“Aware of your preoccupation in the grave situation, still I request you to immediately hold regular virtual review meetings at district, sub-divisional and block levels to put in place the SOPs for the heat action plan. Otherwise, this natural hazard may unnecessarily compound our challenge in containing COVID-19,” Jena stated in the letter.

Title: Border with C'garh poorly guarded near U'kote
Article:
As a precautionary measure to prevent COVID-19, the State Government has decided not to allow the movement of people and vehicles from the other States exempting the transportation of necessary goods during the 21-day nationwide lockdown called by the Prime Minister.

But here it is seen the opposite. Dondasara check post adjoining Chhattisgarh is only 10 km from here. It is poorly guarded by the police. No police personnel are deployed to curb the movement of people from the State of Chhattisgarh where seven persons have been found coronavirus positive by now.

Umarkote is the second largest town of the district and the commercial hugnpub of the district. It completely depends upon the neighbouring State for various purposes. The people from both sides cross the border every day for business purpose in normal time. But the detection of seven coronavirious patients in in Raipur has created havoc here.

Only a few Gram Rakhis have been deployed by the police in the check-post following an outcry of villagers. People are travelling from both sides flouting the very purpose of social distancing.

Title: PNS
Article: The Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat has approved Rs 4 lakh insurance cover each to the 68,457 frontline personnel working for protection against the spread of COVID-19. In the duration of one year, about Rs 17.02 crore will be expended on this. This expenditure will be borne through the CM relief fund. The insurance of Health department personnel has been done by the Central Government. Those who will benefit by the insurance cover being provided by the State government include 22,523 police personnel, 7,988 sanitation workers, 14,595 Anganwadi workers, 14,376 Anganwadi assistants, 4,924 mini Anganwadi assistants, 464 supervisors, 78 CDPOs, nine DPOs, 3,000 personnel of GMVN and KMVN along with 500 personnel of SEOC/DEOC while separate arrangements are being made for media personnel.

Title: Hi-Tech COVID-19 hosp at Parala soon
Article:
As per an MoU signed with the State Government recently, the Hi-Tech Medical College would set up a 200-bed special COVID-19 hospital on the city outskirts here soon to provide treatment to coronavirus patients of Gajapati district.

The hospital would operate in the boys' hostel of the CUTM on a temporary basis for six months. All required equipments and beds have been brought from the Hi-Tech Medical College and Hospital, Bhubaneswar.

Hi-Tech Group Chairman Dr Tirupati Panigrahi said the Government would provide all support for development of infrastructure and an industrial unit would give financial support to the hospital as per the tripartite agreement. Another such hospital would also be set up at Rourkela by the Hi-Tech Group, he said.

Title: Arrangements made in hospitals to treat COVID-19 patients
Article:
The State Government is taking all possible measures to ensure safety from the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19). In such a situation, the cooperation of private medical establishments is very important, said chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat while chairing a meeting with representatives of major hospitals here on Monday.

Rawat said that beds have been reserved for COVID-19 patients at All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Rishikesh, Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital, Himalayan Hospital at Jolly Grant and Mahant Indiresh hospital in Dehradun. Separate arrangements are being made in these hospitals for treatment of COVID-19 patients.

Treatment related equipment is being arranged for as per the requirements.

Four hundred beds each have been reserved in AIIMS, Rishikesh and GDMC hospital for COVID-19 patients. Similarly, 200 beds each have been reserved for such patients in Himalayan Hospital and Mahant Indiresh hospital with scope for increasing the number of beds in these two hospitals if needed.

Further, 200 beds will also be arranged at the Military Hospital in Dehradun. Intensive Care Units and number of ventilators for COVID-19 patients will be increased in such hospitals if needed and ambulances will also be facilitated.

For coordination, IPS officer Neeru Garg has been made the nodal officer for AIIMS Rishikesh and Himalayan Hospital while IPS officer Kewal Khurana has been made the nodal officer for GDMC hospital and Mahant Indiresh hospital.

State minister Dhan Singh Rawat, Mahant Devendra Dass, chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, sub-area GOC major general Rajendra Singh Thakur, Vijay Dhasmana of Himalayan Hospital and AIIMS Rishikesh director Ravikant along with officials concerned were also present in the meeting.

Title: Jagannath Relief Fund to fight corona
Article:
The Shree Jagannath Temple Administration (SJTA) would soon form a relief fund to help the State Government fight the coronavirus (COVID-19). A decision to this effect was taken at a meeting held by the SJTA Finance Committee here on Monday.

The fund would be named “Shree Jagannath Relief Fund”. Devotees from across the globe would be appealed to donate money to help the State Government combat the deadly virus. The collected money would be transferred to the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund (CMRF).

Notably, the Shreemandir has remained closed for devotees since March 20 as a precautionary measure to prevent spread of the coronavirus. But servitors are performing daily rituals of the Trinity in the temple premises.

Title: ‘Farmers to follow social distancing while harvesting crops’
Article:
Appealing farmers to go to the fields for harvesting of their crops by following social distancing norms, Haryana Agriculture and Farmers Welfare Minister Jai Prakash Dalal said that the agriculture department officers have been directed to make all the arrangements ensuring hassle free Rabi procurement season for Mustard starting from April 15, and Wheat from April 20.

He says that to incentivise farmers for staggered and delayed procurement of wheat due to the ongoing lockdown, the government has sent a proposal urging the Central Government to provide incentive ranging from Rs 50 to Rs 125 per quintal to the farmers.

The Agriculture Minister said that to overcome from the shortage of labourers in this harvesting season, the district authorities have been directed to ensure that the combine and other agricultural machinery coming from Punjab and other States are not stopped from entering in the State.

In an interview with ‘The Pioneer’, the Agriculture Minister reveals his strategies to address farmers’ concerns regarding procurement of crops after enforcement of lockdown due to corona virus threat. Excerpts from the interview:

After the announcement of lockdown, how would the farmers harvest Mustard and Wheat and take it to the markets?

Mustard and Wheat are at the maturity stage now. Farmers taking their produce to the mandis for procurement will not be stopped once the season begins. But at the same time, to avoid gathering in large numbers, farmers are being made aware that they are not taking crops together in Mandis. Haryana largely depends on farm labourers from Bihar, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Jharkhand, Orissa and others. They are employed by farmers and the aarhtiyas' commission agents each for harvesting and procurement activities respectively.

Do you think that an acute shortage of labourers and transportation following country-wide lockdown to halt the spread of the coronavirus outbreak, harvesting and procurement of Mustard and Wheat crop has turned into a herculean task for farmers and the State government?

It is true that following lockdown, farmers are facing difficulties to find labourers to cut harvest from their fields in the State. Now, farmers in the State are highly depended on local labourers. We appeal to the farmers to use machines for harvesting and threshing instead. For this, farmers should invite private players from Punjab for the combine and other agricultural machinery for harvesting and threshing of rabi crops. Such machines were also used for the same purpose in previous years too. Only we can ensure that farming machinery coming from Punjab and other States are not stopped from entering in the State. For this, district authorities have already been instructed.

With the announcement of 21-days lockdown, large number labourers are stranded at different places within State. The labour rates have also gone by 25 per cent to 50 per cent. How will you address it?

Farmers have been asked to go to the fields for the harvesting of their crops, provided that they have to follow social distancing norm. They should make an arrangement at their level to cut the harvest from their fields. Many farming families have started harvesting on their own. The Government is mulling to make a new scheme to make for farmers’ losses. Meanwhile, the process to contact the workers of the unorganised sector for providing aid had been initiated and the officials concerned had been directed to ensure that no worker was left out. We have asked the district authorities to provide food and shelter to migrant labourers and the homeless in temporary community shelters in accordance with social distancing norms.

Farmers in the State are worried following unseasonal rain, lack of storage space and closure of shops selling fertilisers and pesticides. What are the steps being taken to mitigate their woes?

Rain at this stage was not required for Wheat crop as it was at the maturity stage. Earlier in March, rain occurred and many farmers had applied for compensation under the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana. State Government has already announced special girdawari (revenue survey) of rabi crops affected due to rain in the beginning of March. Meanwhile, as many farmers have started harvesting their crops, they have been urged to stock the grain at their homes or other suitable places. In case any farmer faces trouble doing the same, the marketing board has been told to look into the matter. Department officers concerned have been asked to address the issues of fertilizers and pesticides immediately.

Owing to lockdown, the State Government there is delay in procurement of wheat and farmers have a critical problem of storage. Private players may take advantage by procuring their crops at a much lower price. Your comment.

The procurement of Mustard and Wheat was scheduled to begin on March 29 and April 1 respectively, Due to unavoidable reason, dates were extended. The harvesting of mustard has started while that of wheat is also likely to begin in the next few days. Hisar and adjoining districts, including Bhiwani, Charkhi Dadri, Fatehabad and Mahendergarh, have mustard as the main rabi crop. Some Mustard farming families have started harvesting on their own. Farmers have been asked to stock the grain at their homes till then. As a part of an arrangement, the sheds of Radha Swami Dera Satsang buildings will be used for purchase. Farmers should not be in hurry. The authorities will take cognisance if such cases arise.

What are the directions given to department officers to address farmers’ concerns?

The officers have been directed to keep in mind that procurement of mustard and wheat is only five days apart, there is a possibility that both crops are procured together. To accommodate both the crops, they have been directed to build separate procurement centers apart from the existing mandis.

Leader of Opposition Bhupinder Singh Hooda raised the concerns of farmers over harvesting amid lockdown. He seeks guidelines from the State Government for harvesting and bonus to compensate the farmers. Your comment

We too are concerned on farmers’ issues. With lockdown till April 14, arrangements are being made to start the procurement of mustard and wheat on April 15 and April 20, respectively, if the situation gets favourable. We are in contact with farmer communities and aware about their pertinent issues. Our Government will take all possible steps to resolve their issues. The Government will come out with new scheme to compensate for farmers’ losses.

What are the prices fixed by the State Government for the procurement of Mustard and Wheat from the farmers this year?

This year, the minimum support price for Mustard has been fixed at Rs 4425 per quintal and Rs 1925 per quintal for Wheat. In the mandis, if the bid price of the crops is less than their minimum support price then the difference is compensated under the Bhavantar Bharpaii Yojana.

Does your government have any plan to incentivise farmers for staggered and delayed procurement?

We are working in this direction. The Central Government has been urged to incentivise farmers for staggered and delayed procurement. The procurement of wheat, which was scheduled to begin on April 1, is now scheduled to begin on April 20. In view of the delayed procurement of wheat due to the ongoing lockdown, the State Government has sent a proposal urging the Central Government’s to provide incentive ranging from Rs 50 to Rs 125 per quintal to the farmers.

Title: Punjab Govt tracking 55,669 foreign-returnees
Article:
Adopting a “4T approach” in tracking the “missing” Non-Resident Indians (NRIs) in the State, Punjab Government is on job to track each of the 55,669 passengers arrived in the State from aboard — as per the list shared by the Central Government.

Maintaining that the figure of 90,000 NRIs or foreign travellers, as earlier quoted, was wrong, the State’s Special Chief Secretary KBS Sidhu said: “The data that we got from New Delhi was quite delayed and contained duplicates. Apart from having incomplete particulars, the address given on the passport often was an old one and it took time to trace the new abode.”

Sidhu said that each of the 55,669 NRIs are being tracked. “The Deputy Commissioner have adopted a 4T approach — trace, track, test, treat. Our protocol is even more strict than GOI,” tweeted Sidhu from his official Twitter handle.

Notably, the Central Government’s Cabinet Secretary Rajiv Gauba, in a letter issued to all the States and Union territories on March 26, had maintained as per the Bureau of Immigration has shared the details of more than 15 lakh international passengers with the States or UTs for monitoring for COVID 19 till March 23, 2020.

Citing “gap between the number of international passengers who need to be monitored by the States or UTs and the actual number of passengers being monitored”, the Centre had asked the States and UTs to take concerted and sustained action urgently to put such passengers under surveillance immediately, and “actively involve” the district authorities in this effort.

As per the Centre’s list, total 55,669 persons arrived from abroad in Punjab, with maximum 13,723 in Jalandhar district.

Leaving nothing to chance, the State Government has also issued a self-declaration form for those all NRIs or foreign travellers who have arrived in Punjab after January 30, 2020, and have not been contacted by Civil Administration, Health and Police Department so far.

“Many NRIs or foreign travellers have already contacted and submitted their details to the concerned authorities in Punjab. But this self-declaration form has been issued for those NRIs or foreign travellers who have arrived in Punjab after January 30, 2020, and have not contacted the offices of respective Deputy Commissioners, Civil Surgeons, Health Department and Police so far,” said the Government spokesperson.

The spokesperson said that all such NRIs or foreign travellers should submit this form at ‘Dial-112’ National Emergency Response System (ERSS) immediately.

“The NRIs or foreign travellers could also furnish their details at ‘Dial-112 App’ (available at Google Play Store) or e-mail their details at ‘dial-112@punjabpolice.gov.in. Apart from this, information could also be submitted at dial 112 portal -http://ners.in/,” said the spokesperson.

The spokesperson added that if anyone is unable to send the requisite details at given email or portal, such details could be sent at WhatsApp number 97799-20404. However, 112 number should only be dialed when one is not able to send information on the given platforms.

“In addition, the NRIs or foreign travellers should have to submit their details such as their date of arrival in Punjab as well as the name of the airport where they landed including the date of landing,” said the spokesperson.

Besides, they have to submit the information pertaining to places of visit in Punjab and their passport number along with their name and contact details such as mobile number, landline number and email-id. They should also furnish their permanent address as per mentioned in their passport, stay in hotel if any and present address where they are residing, he added.

Title: HP to use SDRF to feed people during lockdown
Article:
Himachal Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Monday said funds released under State Disaster Response Fund may now be utilized for provision of food for people stranded in lockdown, which was used earlier for disaster related activities and instructions have been passed to district administration.

In a statement, Thakur said that district administrations are helping the stranded people and it is being ensured that proper arrangements of food and shelter are done for them. Similarly, arrangements have been made in Himachal Bhawan Chandigarh and Delhi for the students and working people of Himachal Pradesh who are living in Chandigarh or Delhi and cannot come back home due to lockdown.

The Chief Minister said that to ensure necessary arrangements for migrant labourers stranded due to lockdown, district wise integrated report has been prepared.

Title: DIPROs asked to identify, quash false news
Article:
Director, Information, Public Relations and Languages Department, PC Meena on Monday directed all the DIPROs of the State to nip fake news in the bud and stay abreast of the situation so that panic is not spread among the people, during a video conferencing.

He said that, as the lockdown progresses a lot of fake news has and will surface on social media about essential commodities and COVID-19 cases, but the officers must ensure that this false news is identified and quashed so that it does not cause panic among the people and the spread of rumors.

Meena said the recent fake news which was being broadcast by one news channel that there has been one COVID-19 death in Faridabad was promptly checked by the officer of the concerned Department and was taken off air. News like this can cause panic, he added.

Title: 2 deaths reported in Punjab in 24 hrs
Article:
Two deaths were reported in Punjab during the past 24 hours taking the total number of casualties to three in the state which also has 41 novel coronavirus positive patients. A day after recording second casualty due to COVID-19, the state on Monday reported three new cases, out of which one patient succumbed to the deadly virus.

On late Sunday night, Punjab’s second death of 62-year-old granthi, who was believed close to the state’s first victim — a 70-year-old man who died almost two weeks ago of coronavirus after he returned from a trip to Germany and Italy — was reported. With the three new cases — one each from Ludhiana, Patiala and SAS Nagar (Mohali), the total number of positive cases in the state has reached 41.

Title: 5 more +ve cases in UT, total 13 now
Article:
Five fresh positive cases of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) were recorded in Chandigarh on Monday taking the total number of cases here to 13. Three primary contacts of eighth positive COVID-19 case have also been tested positive on Monday.

“40 years old mother of the eighth positive case, admitted in isolation ward of GMCH-32 is also tested positive. Two of his other primary contacts including a 23-year old male resident and another 23 years old male resident, both admitted in isolation ward of GMCH-32 are also tested positive,” said an official spokesman.

A NRI couple including 32 years old male and 32 years old female, both residents of Canada who were admitted at isolation ward of GMCH-32, have also been tested positive for COVID-19, the spokesman added. The city had recorded its eighth positive case of COVID-19 on Friday. The 22-year-old man from Chandigarh’s Sector 30 had showed no symptoms for 10 days after returning from Dubai and had reported to a local hospital only on the 15th day. During this period, he came in contact with more than 80 people, who were put under home quarantine.

Title: AIIMS Rishikesh starts COVID-19 test facility
Article:
The second facility to test the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Uttarakhand started on Monday with All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh announcing that its virology lab has started conducting the test. Prior to it the laboratory of the Government Medical College Haldwani was the only facility in the State where tests of COVID-19 were being conducted. The director of the AIIMS Rihsikesh, Ravikant said that the virology lab has got the approval of the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) to conduct the test of COVID-19. The ICMR has also provided the institute 150 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) kits to conduct the test. In the second phase, 300 more kits would be provided. The in-charge of virology lab of AIIMS Rishikesh, Dr Deepjyoti Kalita said that 25 tests per day can be conducted in the laboratory and after two weeks the number of tests would be increased to 50 per day. She said that the institute has trained 10 PG doctors, junior residents and PhD students to conduct the test. Dr Kalita added that as per the protocol of ICMR, three days are needed for releasing the result of a positive test and two days for a negative test.

The staff officer of the AIIMS director, Dr Madhur Uniyal said that 100 bed isolation ward has started functioning at the AIIMS Rishikesh for the patients of the COVID-19 and suspected cases of the disease. He added that the number of beds would be increased further in view of the patients.

Title: THR might get delayed in April by few days
Article:
Due to the State-wide lockdown in Uttarakhand, the distribution of the Take Home Ration (THR) by Anganwadi workers might get delayed in April. The THR is generally distributed on the 5th day of every month by Anganwadi workers across the State under Supplementary Nutrition Programme (SNP) of Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) to children, pregnant women and lactating mothers for 300 days. However, the THR will probably not be distributed on the said day of the next month because the Self Help Groups (SHGs) who provide the food packages to the Anganwadi centres are incapable of doing the same due to the lockdown in the State.

While talking to The Pioneer, the Child Development Project Officer (CDPO) Anju Badola said, "The SHGs have told us that they would not be able to pack and send the packages this time due to the lockdown in their areas. They said that they do not have the complete ration which is included in the list of THR. Therefore, it is possible that the distribution of THR might get delay in April by a few days."

Recently the state president of Anganwadi Workers Association, Rekha Negi had said that the government had issued a direction about Anganwadi workers delivering the THR at the doorsteps of all beneficiaries which Negi refused stating that it could pose the threat of spread of COVID-19. Pertaining to this, Badola said that nothing has been given in writing to anyone for now but if the Anganwadi workers will be ordered by the department to distribute THR by delivering at the home of every beneficiary, the workers cannot do otherwise.

Title: Guv to contribute one-month salary to PM Cares fund
Article:
The Governor Baby Rani Maurya has decided to give her one month salary to PM Cares fund and has appealed to the citizens to contribute their bit by cooperating with the Central and State Governments. On Monday she talked over phone and took information about the arrangements regarding testing and treatment of COVID-19 in three hospitals of the state on Monday. Talking directly to doctors, nurses and laboratory superintendents, she inquired about the health progress and well being of patients of COVID-19. Maurya said that the contribution of doctors, nurses and paramedical staff was very important in the present scenario.

The governor talked to Dr Anita Rawat of the laboratory of Government Sushila Tiwari Hospital, Haldwani, Rameshwari Negi, Assistant nursing superintendent of GDMC hospital and captain Dr Yugank Gupta of Military Hospital. She said that the government is taking every possible step to fight against COVID-19. Every member of the society should cooperate in this.

Title: Lockdown: Cops attacked during patrolling
Article:
Strict enforcement of COVID-19 lockdown took an ugly turn in Chandbali of Bhadrak district when a youth attacked on-duty police personnel during patrolling on Monday.

However, the youth was later arrested and produced before court.

Sources said that an enforcement team headed by Additional Tehsildar Prashant Maharana had gone to Chandbali NAC for patrolling in the morning. Finding a few youths roaming on the road at Baligaon Chhak, the cops reprimanded them and asked them to get back to their homes. When they did not pay attention to the police personnel’s instruction, the cops got off their PCR van to take further action.

When three youths ran away, one named Ramesh Das started hitting the cops with a wooden plank. Two police personnel, including a Constable, were injured in the attack. Later, the cops retaliated and caught hold of the youth, who was also injured in the incident. The cops later admitted him to a hospital for treatment.

The Additional Tehsildar lodged a police complaint, following which the youth was arrested and produced before court, said SDPO Uma Shankar Maharana.

Title: PM Narendra Modi interacts with organisational heads
Article:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi had a video conference with heads of more than a dozen spiritual and social organisations seeking their cooperation in the fight against the spread of COVID-19. During this interaction, the All World Gayatri Parivar (AWGP) head Dr Pranav Pandya reiterated his promise to cooperate in every possible way to fight COVID-19. Stating that Pandya himself was a physician, PM Modi asked him to inform the public in a scientific way about measures to avoid this disease.

Pandya informed that more than 5,000 Pragya Institutes of AWGP spread across the country are sending food packets for those in need apart from the contribution being made to PM and CM relief funds. Praising the selfless attitude of the AWGP, PM Modi described it as an inspiration for the entire society.

It should be mentioned here that apart from Dr Pandya, Bhaiyyaji Joshi of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, Sri Sri Ravishankar of Art of Living, Swami Ramdev of Patanjali Yogpeeth, Jaggi Vasudeva and representative of Ramakrishna Mission among other such organisations were part of the video conference.

Title: No collection: B’swar DHH runs short of blood
Article:
At the time of the coronavirus spread, the blood bank at the District Headquarters Hospital (DHH) here is experiencing an imminent threat to its stock as blood of different groups including rare ones is exhausting with no inflow.

The DHH usually collects about 1,500-1,600 units of blood averagely per month from voluntary collection through camps by different organisations. But the stock is drying up due to non-collection ever since the lockdown.

About 800 thalassimia patients depend on the DHH for blood at regular intervals. About 400 units of blood are used by delivery patients. As a whole, about 1,200 units of blood are needed per month.

Blood Bank Officer Basant Kumar Upadhyay said the bank could face acute shortage of blood if fresh collection is not made.

“Since blood collection camps are not possible under the prevailing circumstances, volunteers can come to the bank and donate blood to save the lives of the needy,” appealed Upadhyay.

Meanwhile, Chief District Medical Officer BP Chhotray informed that till Sunday health screening of 233 persons who arrived from abroad was carried out and 182 of them were under home quarantine. Besides, health checkup for 12,910 people, who came from other States, was conducted.

Title: 2 buses seized while trying to ferry migrants using fake passes
Article:
Two buses were seized and their operator was booked after the buses were caught trying to ferry migrant workers using fake passes on Sunday night. Following Home ministry orders to seal inter-state borders, city superintendent of police Kamlesh Upadhyay was in the field when she saw a couple of buses with about 80 passengers travelling toward Shyampur from Chandighat. Stopping the buses to check, she found that the passes displayed were fake.

Considering the seriousness of the situation, the district magistrate C Ravishankar and SSP Senthil Avoodai reached the spot after checking the scene, ordered strict action against the guilty.

The DM said that contrary to the Home ministry orders, some vehicles were plying Lucknow, Varanasi and Prayagraj using fake passes. How the fake passes were secured is a matter of investigation. Since the issuance of passes is being done by the district administration, strict action will taken against any government employee found guilty in this case, he stressed.

The SSP said that two buses had been seized while ferrying about 150 labourers and some others to West Bengal, Lucknow and Prayagraj. The police have lodged FIR against travel agency owner Ajay Chaudhary under sections 188, 336, 420, 467, 468 and 471 of IPC. The Ranipur, Haridwar resident has been detained.

Title: Samanta pledges Rs 2.5 cr MPLAD fund
Article:
After donating his three months’ salary, Kandhamal BJD MP and KIIT and KISS founder Achyuta Samanta has pledged Rs 2.5 crore from his MPLAD funds to support the State Government’s efforts in fighting the coronavirus.

In a letter, Dr Samanta urged the Kandhamal Collector for a one-time dispensation of Rs 2.50 crore from his MPLAD funds for urchase of testing and screening kit and other medical equipment for the districts of Kandhamal, Boudh, Ganjam and Nayagarh to bolster the anti-COVIID-19 battle.

Rs 110 lakh would be spent for Kandhamal district, Rs 70 lakh for Boudh snd Rs 35 lakh each for Ganjam and Nayagarh.

Title: Observing lockdown, social distancing vital to defeat COVID-19, reiterates CM
Article:
Appealing the people yet again to maintain social distancing and observe the lockdown properly, Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said that with the cooperation of the public, Uttarakhand can win against COVID-19.

0Addressing the people through Facebook live on Monday, the CM said that a number of Uttarakhandis outside the state want to return but in the current situation, people need to remain where they are. The Government of India has directed all the State Governments to facilitate food and other arrangements for stranded people from other states. There will be some inconvenience but one has to observe vigilance and patience in these testing times.

He said, “We are getting to hear that people in some villages of Uttarakhand are playing volleyball, cricket and cards, which is not good. It is vital to maintain social distancing and observe the lockdown effectively. Maintain distance from your children too for some days to save your family, yourself and your village. Look at what happened in countries like Italy and Spain where this was taken lightly.” Rawat also said that necessary arrangements have been made for the number of tourists and labourers from other states currently in Uttarakhand. Only with the cooperation of all will the State be able to win against COVID-19, he stressed.

Title: Jilted lover cuts off his genitals
Article:
In a bizarre incident, a youth cut off his genitals and threw it in a Yajna Kunda in Nayagarh district on Sunday.

The 24-year-old youth of Shathipalli village under the Nayagarh Town police limits chopped off his penis and sacrificed it in Yajna Kunda after his love proposal was rejected by a girl.

The youth was reportedly having a one-sided love affair with the girl from the same village. As his proposal was spurned, he got frustrated.

The youth was initially admitted to the District Headquarters Hospital in critical condition and later shifted to the Capital Hospital, Bhubaneswar when his condition worsened.

Title: 58 pilgrims quarantined in Rourkela
Article:
As many as 58 passengers, including driver and helper of a bus, were sent to quarantine here on Monday soon after they returned from a pilgrimage in Uttar Pradesh.

The tourists, residents of Balangir and Subarnapur districts, had gone to Mathura and Vrindavan before announcement of the lockdown. The local administration made transport arrangements for their return to Odisha.

They returned via Rourkela passing through the Jharkhand border. On their arrival on Monday, the local administration sent them to the Ispat General Hospital (IGH) for a primary health checkup. All of them were stated to be COVID-19 negative.

However, they all were sent to an isolation centre developed by the Rourkela Municipal Corporation (RMC) at Chhend for 14 days.

Title: IMA assures full support in fight against COVID-19
Article:
Beds have been reserved in GDMC hospital, Mahant Indiresh Hospital, AIIMS, Rishikesh and Himalayan Hospital for COVID-19 patients and doctors in these hospitals have been deputed for treatment of COVID-19 cases. In such a scenario the responsibility of private hospitals has also increased. All the private hospitals and nursing homes should keep their OPDs open so that citizens afflicted by other health issues can access treatment conveniently, said chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat while chairing a meet with office bearers of the Indian Medical Association (IMA) on Monday.

The CM said that the government will provide all type of assistance to the private medical institutions. He directed the police-administration to assist in keeping the OPDs in private hospitals proper. The IMA office bearers assured Rawat that full cooperation will be provided to the government in the efforts against spread of novel coronavirus. This is a fight which involves the whole society and nation, not just the government, they said.

State minister Dhan Singh Rawat, chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, IMA Uttarakhand head Dr Ajay Khanna, CMI chairman Dr RK Jain, Dr Mahesh Kuriyal, Dr DD Choudhary and Dr Krishna Avtar among others were present in the meeting.

Title: Car hits bike, truck in Khordha; 2 die
Article:
A motorcycle rider and a car driver were killed in a series of accidents occurred on National Highway-16 at the Rameswar petrol pump under the Nirakar police limits in Khordha district on Monday.

A car first hit a motorcycle and then rammed into a stationary truck. The two deceased died on the spot. They were yet to be identified. Police reached the spot and started investigation.

Title: Provide help to needy: Pritam Singh to Congress leaders
Article:
The Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) President Pritam Singh has asked all the party leaders and workers to help the needy in their areas. He has appealed the member of parliaments, MLAs, MLA candidates of 2017 elections, AICC and PCC members, district and city presidents, block and presidents, heads of ancillary organisations and Nagar Palika and Nagar Panchayat presidents belonging to the party that due to the crisis created by the novel Coronavirus, large number of people require help and the congressmen should do their best to provide necessary assistance to them.

The PCC president has also written a letter to chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat in which he has requested him to make arrangements to bring back the residents of Uttarakhand who are stranded in other States due to lockdown. He said that the government is making arrangement of buses for return of residents of Gujarat stranded in Uttarakhand to their home state. Singh said these buses should bring back the people of Uttarakhand stranded in Gujarat. He said that the Uttarakhand Government should interact with other state governments for ensuring safe return of people of Uttarakhand stranded there. In his letter, the PCC president said that the Congress workers are assisting the administration in their areas in providing help to the needy.

He said that the administration should reach out to the people residing in remote areas and help them. Meanwhile, the former PCC chief, Kishore Upadhyaya has said that the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) should come forward and help people at this time of crisis. On his Facebook post, Upadhyaya said RSS has 60,000 branches and more than 60 lakh members across the country.

Title: Lockdown strengthens family members’ bond
Article:
The lockdown may have broken the usual busy schedule of life, but nonetheless it has brought the family members closer.

Kalpana Mohanty, a homemaker in Kendrapada district, is taking time off to read the book she had purchased a month ago, while her husband is making breakfast for her and the kids, a departure from the usual practice at her home, where morning scenes before the lockdown were all about preparing tiffin boxes and sending children to school.

Mohanty and many others like her are making the most of this quarantine period to spend time with family, playing card games, binge watching TV shows together and turning the pages of albums of photographs.

People in different parts of the State have been abiding by the lockdown regulations and refraining from venturing out unless it is very urgent, Bhubaneswar-based lawyer CK Mohanty said.

“Now, indoor confinement has strengthened the family bonding that used to be punctuated by hectic schedules of daily life. For those missing the feelings of togetherness, the prevailing situation has come as a blessing in disguise,” said Dipti, a homemaker in the State capital.

Sabita Kanungo of Pattamundai said Kendrapada district has witnessed homecoming of thousands of migrant workers, both from within and outside the country.

“My husband is a teacher of a Government school, which is now shut in view of coronavirus scare. The classes are suspended and the Government has asked the teachers not to go to school. His presence at home almost round-the-clock has enlivened the family environment. That was missing earlier,” Ranjita Mishra, a homemaker of Kendrapada town, said.

No doubt, fear remains in their minds, but families stand united in the battle against COVID-19, said Bikramjit, a senior executive at a private company, where work is temporarily suspended.

Pratiti Mohanty, a resident of Bhubaneswar, said her advocate husband now confines himself to home as courts are not functioning. “My son and daughter are also at home as educational institutions remain shut. The lockdown has given a boost to indoor family activities,” she added.

Title: 11 foreign returnees’ samples sent for tests
Article:
District health officials, in the last two days, have sent the swab samples of 10 foreign returnees to the district to the Bhubaneswar-based Regional Medical Research Centre (RMRC) for coronavirus tests, said Jharsuguda CDMO JC Barik on Monday.

These persons are on home quarantine on their return. As many as 51 persons, who returned from abroad remained under home quarantine, out of which the quarantine period of 25 persons have been completed. Still, they are kept under close watch. On receipt of reports, further action would be taken, Barik added.

Department sources said that around 1,400 persons, who arrived in the district from other States, have been kept under home quarantine.

Meanwhile, police have booked cases against two persons, including a woman, for venturing out of their homes during the quarantine period. Both had arrived here from overseas.

Title: Dhabas, tyre repair shops open in K’put
Article:
As advised by the State Government, the Koraput district administration has allowed opening of 10 dhabas (roadside eateries) and tyre repairing shops along the highways for smooth movement of trucks carrying essential commodities during the coronavirus lockdown period.

While dhabas would provide packed cooked foods to drivers and helpers, the tyre repairing shops would remain open to check pressure in tyres and repair punctured tyres.

Dhaba owners have been asked to engage fewer number of workers and to maintain hygienic conditions. Besides, they have been asked to avoid congregation of any degree and not to supply food to any other people.

Title: 145 cases registered, 3,750 people detained
Article:
The Delhi Police registered 145 cases and 3,750 people were detained for violating government orders during the coronavirus lockdown. According to the data shared by the police, 145 cases were registered under section 188 (for disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code till 5pm.

A total of 3,750 people have been detained under section 65 (persons bound to comply with reasonable directions of police officers) and 557 vehicles have been impounded under section 66 of the Delhi Police Act, they stated. A total of 2143 movement passes have been issued.

Title: SDMC buys 14K nitrile gloves to ensure safety of medical workers
Article:
The South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) has procured 14,000 special Nitrile gloves to ensure the safety of its medical staff and sanitation workers who are working relentlessly to prevent the spread of Coronavirus. The civic body has also decided to use jetting machines for sanitising public places.

A senior SDMC official said that n each zone 3500 gloves will be distributed to the staff. According to health officials, these gloves are very useful and long lasting; each glove will be last for 15 days. It has to be washed with soap daily.

The official said that disposable nitrile rubber gloves are waterproof, greaseproof, oil proof and most importantly, chemical resistant to a range of common chemicals and substances. These gloves are used by medical professionals as it has excellent chemical resistance and puncture strength and dexterous strength, he said.

To further intensify the cleaning and sanitation drives, SDMC has also decided to use jetting machines for sprinkling sanitizers in public areas using sodium hypo-Chloride solutions and bleaching solutions for disinfecting public places.

Apart from this, 15 tankers are continually operating and spraying disinfectants mainly near food distribution centers, public areas, surrounding areas of quarantined houses across four zones. All the sanitization drives are being closely monitored by the area councillor.

SDMC is also ensuring that public toilets are being sanitized with bleaching solution daily to control community spread of coronavirus.

Apart from above mentioned gloves, SDMC is also providing 2000 mask to each zone in addition to already supplied.

Title: Min visits juvenile homes, takes stock of situation
Article:
Delhi Women and Child Development Minister Rajendra Pal Gautam visited several juvenile observational homes across Delhi to take a stock of all the appropriate precautions being taken to tackle coronavirus. Notably, Union Government and Delhi Government issued several guidelines and precautions which must be taken to prevent the transmission of coronavirus

Gautam ordered an immediate ban on the visiting of family members in the juvenile homes. The residents will be able to contact their families twice a week by phone, which earlier used to happen only once.

Special instructions were given to the authorities that there should be minimum visitors in the home and proper hygiene and cleanliness should be the topmost priority.

“The only way to avoid corona is to preventing its transmission completely. Keeping this in view, i have ordered that there should be strict control on the number of people visiting the homes. Nobody should enter the homes without sanitizing their hands which is why we are making sure that sanitizer is available right at the gate. The health of all children and youth living here will be given priority. The measures have been taken in the light of their health,” said Gautam

There are currently 29 youth in the Observation Homes at Delhi Gate with a capacity of 75 people, out of which 6 were released on bail.

Similarly, the Observation Home, with a capacity of 100 youth, has 103 residents, of whom 24 are released on bail and 2 will be released by evening.

There are 65 youths in the 50-capacity Place for Safety Majnu Ka Tila, of which 9 were granted bail. SPYM located at Sewa Kutir where there are 40 youths with 10 released on bail.

Title: Pb launches special helpline for advice on medical, stress, anxiety related issues
Article:
To effectively address and resolve medical and stress related issues during lockdown, Punjab Government on Monday launched a special helpline ‘1800-180-4104’ for citizens to connect with a network of senior doctors over tele-conference and get medical advice on COVID-19 and other related concerns.

“As many as 1,800 senior doctors have been empanelled through the IMC for the purpose who have been duly trained about the platform, its protocol and functionalities,” said the state Additional Chief Secretary (Governance Reforms and Public Grievances) Vini Mahajan.

Underlining the importance of the helpline, Mahajan said that an intelligent Coronavirus Triaging System has been developed to identify and prioritize cases for emergency medical attention. “This system will also help identify cases for isolation, home quarantine and those who require medical attention. The cases shall be notified to the government for further tracking and action,” she added. The helpline has been conceptualized by the Department of Governance Reforms and Public Grievances and is being implemented with the State COVID19 Control Room, Punjab Government (SCCR), and the India Medical Association (IMA), Punjab State Branch.

Title: Railways uninterrupted freight services for essential commodities
Article:
While the country is completely locked down due to the pandemic of coronavirus, Indian Railways continues to work round the clock to ensure availability of essential commodities through its uninterrupted freight services.

The Indian Railway loaded 684 rakes and 35,319 wagons on Sunday out of which 437 rakes and 24,202 wagons were full of essential commodities.

A senior railway official said that 40 rakes and 1727 wagons were loaded with food grains, five rakes and 210 wagons of sugar, one rake and 42 wagons of salt, one rake and 42 wagons of edible oil, 363 rakes and 20,904 wagons of coal, 27 rakes and 1277 wagons of petroleum products.

Similarly, on Saturday, 695 rakes and 35,942 wagons were loaded out of which 442 rakes and 24412 wagons were loaded with essential commodities (One wagon contains 58-60 ton consignment). “This includes 54 rakes and 2,405 wagons of food grains, three rakes and 126 wagons of sugar, one rake and 42 wagons of salt, one rake and 50 wagons of edible oil, 356 rakes and 20,519 wagons of coal, 27 rakes and 1270 wagons of petroleum products,” the Railways said in a statement.

It may be noted that Ministry of Home Affairs has allowed movement of goods across the country to ensure that supply chain keeps fully operational.

Ministry of Railways and MHA officials are in constant touch with State Governments to sort out operational issues to ensure smooth handling at terminal.

In its continuous effort to fight against COVID – 19, the northern railway workshops have been geared up to manufacture 700 liters sanitizer per day, 700 face masks per day. At least1600 face masks have already been manufactured in northern railway.

In order to ensure availability of essential items to different parts of India and to mitigate the effect of lockdown during COVID -19, Northern railway has decided to run six parcel special trains across India.

Title: AAP MLAs distribute food to daily wagers, migrants
Article:
The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) MLAs have started distributing food to the daily wage workers and migrants in their constituency. The party MLAs has also created a WhatsApp groups in their respective Assembly consisting of social organisations and NGOs to facilitate the entire process.

The party MLAs had submitted a list of locations where new night shelters and food distribution centres can be established for the needy. Based on the input from the MLAs, the Delhi Government has now established new shelters and food distribution centres.

“The party MLAs and workers are working tirelessly on ground to ensure food distribution to poor people affected by lockdown in their area. The lockdown has severely affected the lives of many poor people, daily-wagers and labourers. Therefore, the Delhi government has not only started free food distribution through night shelters but has also set up food distribution centres,” the party said in a statement.

AAP MLA from Uttam Nagar Naresh Baliyan distributed dry food packets and almost 10,000 packets of 5 kg flour and 10,000 packets of 1 kg rice to the poor people in his constituency. He has also set up 200 WhatsApp groups in Uttam Nagar Assembly consisting of social organisations and NGOs to facilitate the entire process.

“All these organisations are working with the MLA to ensure no one stays hungry in the area. Mr Balayan had also submitted a list of locations where new night shelters can be built and new food distribution centres can be opened. The Delhi government has made necessary arrangements as per the requirements raised by the MLA,” it said.

Another Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) MLA Praveen Kumar from Jungpura said that his team is feeding almost 5000 people daily. “We are distributing food in 18 police stations areas, 2000 packets two times a day. Apart from this we have identified several locations where we are distributing food through our volunteer teams. Our team is also involved in facilitating distribution of ration,” he added.

Kuldeep Kumar, MLA from Kondli said, "Many people who were leaving Delhi, have returned after listening to the appeal made by Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal. We have made adequate arrangements for their stay and food"

National Spokesperson and AAP MLA Mr Raghav Chadha said, "At this tough time, Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has made sure that no one goes to sleep hungry. Today, at Rajendar Nagar Legislative Assembly, I have distributed free food at eight places. We are ensuring social distancing while distributing food,”

“We are working round the clock to ensure sanitizers, food and water for the poor people of the area. There is no need to worry, we are all together working for the relief," said AAP MLA from Timarpur Dilip Pandey.

"The Delhi Government is providing 1.5 times extra ration to the ration card holder residents of Delhi. Today I ensured that in my area all the ration cardholders get this benefit and the initiative was successful," said MLA from Burari Sanjeev Jha.

Title: Sigh of relief for stranded students in TN, K’taka
Article:
Several students and tribal residents of Jharkhand currently stranded in Tamilnadu and Karnataka may take a sigh of relief after the respective Governments of the two States responded to the request of Chief Minister Hemant Soren to provide relief to them.

Following the CM's request, the Tamil Nadu Government has assured to provide necessary help to the students stranded in Coimbatore. The Tamil Nadu CM said that it has been instructed to make arrangements for food and lodging for the students and people coming to Vellore for treatment. Soren has thanked the Tamil Nadu CM for this help.

Similarly, accepting the request of the Soren, the Karnataka government has assured to provide help to 281 tribal brothers of Khunti stuck in Mangalore. The Karnataka government was told by the Chief Minister that the stranded people would be covered with all necessary help.

The CM said that all the people of Jharkhand living outside the State should remember that they are not alone in this disaster. “The entire State government is with you. Due to the country-wide lockdown, it is not possible to bring all of you back to Jharkhand, but help will surely reach you. I am again requesting you with folded hands; stay where you are. This is the most effective and safe way to avoid this epidemic. I am in touch with the Chief Ministers of all the states. So that help and necessary facilities reach you as soon as possible. The more you stay at home, the more you and your kin will be protected,” he added.

Meanwhile, the CM has ordered Deputy Commissioner Palamu to ensure strict compliance of the lockdown. The CM said that it should also be ensured that such a situation does not occur.

The CM came to know that social distancing is not being followed in lockdown in Haidarnagar market in Palamu. Fair like atmosphere in the market. After this, the Chief Minister has given the order in view of the possible possibility of spreading the infection.

The CM has also ordered DC Dhanbad to inform the Punjabi people working in a company with necessary help. He also said that the company, in which they were employed, should not bear financial loss. The employees should get their full rights. The CM was informed by sharing a video that the company, in which the people work, is not being provided food and there is a nationwide lockdown. In such a situation, their life is difficult.

The Chief Minister has directed Deputy Commissioner Bokaro to resolve the problems being faced by cleaning staff. The Chief Minister said that by sending a team, take stock of the situation and inform them by providing appropriate help. The CM was informed that due to the lockdown, about 200 cleaning staff living in three settlements located in Bokaro are not getting food. Daily wages are also closed due to lockdown.

Title: Vedanta L’garh runs with COVID measures
Article:
Vedanta’s alumina refinery at Lanjigarh is operational with all precautionary measures against COVID-19 as advised by the Government and the health authorities.

Considering the severity of the situation in the wake the spread of Corona, the plant is running with minimum workforce and resources ensuring the COVID-19 guidelines issued by the Central and State authorities.

The plant has all due permissions from the concerned authorities to continue its operations, with all the precautionary and preventive measures in place. The plant has ensured social distancing, sanitization, hygiene, restricted movement etc., within the plant periphery and the township proactively and communicated all necessary approaches to restrict the spread of the virus, said its release.

Vedanta’s 20-bedded hospital at Lanjigarh would provide support to the district administration.

Title: UTC MD: Sealed Haryana border prevented UTC bus from bringing back natives
Article:
Taking cognisance of reports about an Uttarakhand Transport Corporation bus transporting about 50 natives of Uttarakhand back from Gujarat being dropped at the Haryana border, the chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat directed the transport corporation managing director to examine the case.

After examining the case, the corporation managing director Ranbir Chauhan informed the CM that about 55 Uttarakhandis were being ferried by bus from Gujarat. However, the Haryana border was completely sealed due to the lockdown.

The police there stopped the bus and refused to permit the transport of any passenger in the bus.

A number of other buses were also stopped at the site.

The ticket inspector of the bus repeatedly requested the police to let the bus through but was warned that the bus would be seized by the police. The police did not allow any bus to move ahead with passengers.

The passengers were made to disembark and the buses were dispatched, said Chauhan.

Title: Lord’s chariot will not roll in Bhubaneswar
Article:
The chariot was on the verge of completion before the decision was taken. Batakrushna Maharana, the chief carpenter who has been heading the artisans, is a disappointed man. For the first time in living memory, the age-old tradition of Rukuna Rath Yatra of Lord Lingaraj that falls on April 1 this year has been suspended due to the coronavirus outbreak.

The Rukuna Rath Yatra is believed to be “Papa Binashakari Yatra” (which destroys and eradicates all evil and sins). It is the biggest festival of the temple city. The weeklong festival is the high point of festivities in which locals throng with great fervour. This year, a miniature replica of the Rukuna Rath was showcased in the Odisha tableau during the Republic Day parade at New Delhi. The Rukuna Rath Yatra is believed to predate Lord Jagannath’s Rath Yatra at Puri.

Batakrushna Maharana said 75 carpenters had been working for the last three weeks. Nearly a thousand logs had been collected; new wheels and axles had been made. Four new Nahakas and two new Oras were constructed this year. Five tailors had nearly finished the work. Only the painting of the chariot was to be done.

Another uniqueness associated with the Rukuna Rath Yatra is the auction of Marichi Kund water which is held at the Mukteswar Temple. The belief that imbibing the water cures infertility if taken on the penultimate night of the Rath Yatra draws many hopefuls each year.

Title: LNJP, GB Pant hospitals’ docs to get 5-star accommodation
Article:
The doctors treating coronavirus patients at LNJP and GBP hospitals will be accommodated at a private hotel here on Delhi Government's expense, said an order from the Delhi Health Department.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said the doctors are on the frontlines of the battle against coronavirus. All doctors, serving in Delhi Government's Lok Nayak Hospital and GB Pant Hospital on COVID-19 duty, will now be housed in Hotel Lalit. This arrangement has been made to quarantine these doctors. The Delhi Government will bear all the cost of accommodations.

Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain said every doctor would be given a separate room. This is a precautionary measure to keep these doctors away from their families so that there is no chance of spreading of the virus if anyone is infected.

The order issued by the Health Department noted, "It has been decided that doctors working on COVID-19 duty at LNJP Hospital and GB Pant Hospital would be provided accommodation at Hotel Lalit and the payment of the same shall be borne by the Delhi Government."

The district magistrate of New Delhi would make necessary arrangements to make 100 rooms available at the hotel on Barakhamba Road. The LNJP Hospital, GBP Hospital and other few hospitals are among the facilities where doctors are deployed round-the-clock for attending positive or suspected cases of COVID-19.

"The doctors are working 24*7 to treat the COVID-19 positive patient, therefore, it is our duty to ensure a suitable and safe arrangement for them. This is a quarantine facility so that the family members do not come in contact with the doctors. Each of them will get one separate room and the doctors will work in shifts," said Jain.

The Delhi has come with a 14-day shift, 14-day quarantine plan for health workers and medical professionals who are on coronavirus duty in hospitals. The plan will keep the spread of coronavirus in check.

Meanwhile, the Delhi Government has taken several measures to fight the coronavirus.

The administration is ensuring free food to nearly 4 lakh people daily and is providing free ration to 71 lakh people in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis.

More than 800 centres for food and over 1,000 shops for ration have been made operational. 234-night shelters across Delhi are open to accommodate needy people and those hit by the lockdown.

“The administration is also working toward converting schools into shelters to accommodate migrant workers and daily wage labourers,” a Government official said.

Title: Haryana seals borders to stop migrants’ entry
Article:
In a bid to control and stop the movement of migrant labourers and workers across the State, Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar has directed the Deputy Commissioners (DC’s) to completely seal the inter and intra-State borders.

According to the directions by the CM, the migrants should be stopped at their respective places and no one should be allowed to move from the current locations.

The CM ordered the officers concerned to set up shelter or relief camps and ensure that proper food, boarding and lodging arrangements were made for the migrant labourers staying in such camps and if anyone still opposes, strict action should be taken against them.

However, the Gurugram district administration has already set up four shelter homes, that can house almost 600 people, for workers from other states stranded in the city due to the lockdown.

According to officials, one shelter home capable of accommodating 350 people has been set up near IMT Manesar on the Delhi-Jaipur national highway. Food will be provided to the occupants.

Other three are at the community centre on Gurugram-Sohna road near Bhondsi village (150 people), at Bhim Nagar (40 people), and at Kadipur village (50 people).

“Since a lot of people work in IMT Manesar, the capacity of this shelter home is bigger than the others. I appeal to people from other states who reside in Gurugram to come to the shelter homes and not leave the city,” said Deputy Commissioner, Gurugram Amit Khatri.

The district has so far reported 10 cases of Coronavirus out of which five patients who recovered have been discharged, said CMO Jaswant Singh Punia. These include the first person who tested positive, a 29-year-old woman who had returned from Malaysia and Indonesia on February 22, as well as a couple from Nirvana Country, where the man had recently returned from London.

The other two are a 22-year-old studying in London who had returned home on March 14, as well as her 16-year-old brother.

Also, In the last 5 days, however, no new cases have emerged, according to officials from the health department.

Title: Police receive 6,088 lockdown-related calls on 24x7 helpline
Article:
The Delhi Police has received 6,088 calls on their 24x7 helpline number, 011-23469526, to resolve issues related to lockdown. Police received 1,187 calls have been received from Saunday 2 pm to Monday 2 pm.

According to police, out of 1,187, police recieved 278 calls were related to outside Delhi, which have been referred to respective State helpline numbers. Total 76 calls were received related to no food/no money, which have been forwarded to NGO for direct relief at their addresses.

Meanwhile 18 calls were received regarding medical issues and have been resolved through proper guidance to proceed in case of such emergencies, police said.

While 592 calls were related to movement passes and were advised to approach respective jurisdictional Additional DCP-I office.

The food delivery network established in all 15 districts with involvement of nearly 400 NGOs/RWAs/Good Smartians facilitated by Delhi Police has led to provision of meals and food packets at more than 250 locations which enabled feeding of nearly 1,45,000 persons and dry ration to 1385 persons.

Title: Online classes for students of Govt schools: Sisodia
Article:
While countrywide lockdown in the wake of deadly coronavirus has put a “stop” to all outdoor activities to mitigate chances of community transmission, the Delhi Government is going digital to educate wards of its schools.

The Delhi Government on Monday announced that students from nursery to class 8 will be promoted to the next class in the national Capital.

Secondly, online classes are being started for class XII and X students and third, interactive session with SMS, Interactive Voice Response ( IVR) and TV mediums up to eighth standards. The decision to this effect was announced by th e Directorate of Education ( DoE ) after detailed consultation with stake holders in education sector announced these steps on Monday.

According to Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia, it is required to engage students as schools are shut.

Taking care of education of students in continuation of lockdown span with recent riot incidents in Delhi vicinity, Sisodia said that the Government has prepared its action plans to engage students in learning activities via modern day —virtual classes with the help World Wide Web.

Addressing Delhi through live video conference, Sisodia said his Government is promoting the students up to class VII under Government policies —no detention and Right To Education ( RTE ).

Elaborating further on plan A — Sisodia who is a Education and Finance Minister in Aam Aadmi Party ( AAP ) Cabinet, he explained, the promoted students will be engaged with the help of SMS, IVR and TV medium. “Our teachers will send activity projects to students via possible medium of communication, these teachers will prepare an assessment report of these activities which might be considered in grading in near future,” Sisodia said.

While class X result is yet to be announced, Sisodia said that classes will resume for XI standard as it was earlier since there is no further announcement on lockdown extension.

For class XII,the Delhi Government is starting online classes form first week of April and for this Delhi Government has designed an online platform where wards/parents can register.

Most importantly, the Delhi Government is providing free data packages for online learning.

“Students and parents will register themselves to obtain classes, initially we will start with two subjects, details will shared soon,” Education Minister announced.

He further said that the Delhi Government will soon provide this online learning/ classes facility to Class X students.

Title: Doctors’ body sounds alarm over ventilator crisis
Article:
While no cases of COVID-19 have been reported in Jharkhand so far, the State might have a tough time dealing with severe cases of Coronavirus infections in case of an outbreak as the health machinery here lacks ventilators —a machine that provides mechanical ventilation by moving breathable air into and out of lungs —doctors warned on Monday.

However, a highly placed source in the Health Department here rubbished the claims, and said that the hue and cry over ventilators was a result of misconceptions among people. As per figures provided by the countries that are worst-affected by the pandemic, only two to three per cent of patients require to be put on ventilators, he said. “In order to use 200 ventilators, we will have to have around 10000 patients. Right now, we do not have a single case in Jharkhand,” he said.

The Jharkhand chapter of Indian Medical Association (IMA) claimed that the State may witness an explosion of cases due to the allegedly poor screening process in place, and it may run out of life-saving ventilators. “We may witness an explosion, a blast of cases here,” said Dr. Pradeep Kumar, President of IMA Jharkhand. “The shortage of ventilators has affected developed countries like the US and Italy. The only way we can tackle this pandemic is by not letting it reach a stage where ventilators are required,” he added.

According to figures with the Health Department, the State has a total of 232 ventilators as on March 30. Besides, Health Minister Banna Gupta has asked the Centre to provide 300 more ventilators in order to address medical exigencies, a close aide of the minister said on Monday.

Principal Secretary, Health Department, Nitin Madan Kulkarni said that the State was following all the guidelines laid down by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and paying attention to prevention at present. “We have 232 ventilators and we have placed orders for 300 more ventilators. All the guidelines of ICMR are being strictly followed here,” he said.

Ranchi Civil Surgeon Dr. VB Prasad said that there were around 175 ventilators – including the ones in private hospitals – in Ranchi alone, and cases requiring ventilation would be addressed. “We are trying our level best to be prepared for any medical emergency,” he said.

Meanwhile, doctors from IMA have also raised concern over the screening process in Jharkhand claiming that only a fraction of people traveling from other States were tested. “Only using a thermometer to check a traveler’s body temperature is eyewash in the name of screening. Proper tests should be conducted. So many labourers have come to Jharkhand from severely-affected States and they were sent home without any tests,” said Dr. Pradip Kumar.

According to sources in the Health Department, Jharkhand has around 4000 testing kits. At present samples are collected and tested only at two hospitals – Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS) in Ranchi and Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MHM) Hospital in Jamshedpur.

Samples of more than 200 suspected patients in Jharkhand have been tested so far and none of them came out positive, officials from the National Health Mission (NHM) said.

Title: Strict action against black marketeers: DC
Article:
Bokaro DC Mukesh Kumar held meetings with senior officials regarding coronavirus infection. He asked the officials to ensure that food items reach among all the needy and poor without any constraints. The DC said that there is no shortage of food items in the district. Administration asked to take strict action if any shopkeeper reported to involved in black marketing alsoKeeping in mind the facilities and demand of the people, work has been done to install vegetable, fruits, ration shops at places from where the common people can purchase the necessary items at the scheduled time easily.The DC gave strict instructions that those who spread the rumours about Coronavirus infection will be identified and necessary legal action to be taken. The DC also directed all the Block Development Officers and all the Zonal Officers to keep 50 bed quarantines in all blocks and at least 20 beds in all Panchayats ready as proactive measures & also good schools both private & government in all the blocks and all panchayats have also been directed to keep the quarantine ready so that it can be used as per the requirement in any odd situation.

Kumar specifically told all the Block Development Officers and all the Circle Officers that to make the villagers aware, everyone has been asked to increase social distance but during this time they can reduce the emotional distance and talk to their relatives, old friends for extending moral support.

Title: Zero tolerance towards lockdown violators
Article:
DGP Abhay on Monday warned of zero tolerance towards the COVID-19 lockdown violators. He said that while 90 per cent of the people are abiding by the lockdown guidelines, 10 per cent are flouting it, thereby putting the lives of the overwhelming majority in danger.
